summary: This document is a compilation of media articles and social media posts from July 2019 to March 2020 focusing on Ghislaine Maxwell following Jeffrey Epstein's arrest and death. It shows her becoming a primary media target, facing public threats and a bounty, and her subsequent lawsuit against Epstein's estate citing death threats.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.role: Accused enabler and associate of Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The central subject of the media analysis; described as Epstein's 'Lady of the House,' a target of public threats and a bounty, and later as suing Epstein's estate.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Referenced as the central figure in the case, with Maxwell described as his long-entangled associate and 'pal.' His death is noted as elevating Maxwell to 'Person #1' in the case.

connections.description: Described as long-entangled, with Maxwell referred to as Epstein's 'pal' and the 'Lady of the House.' Implied to be a close associate in the alleged criminal enterprise.

events.title: NYT profiles Ghislaine Maxwell
events.description: The New York Times publishes an article profiling Ghislaine Maxwell as 'The Lady of the House' long entangled with Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: Media outlets target Epstein's 'gang'
events.description: The New York Post and Washington Post publish articles focusing on Epstein's alleged enablers and 'recruiters,' with lawyers for accusers vowing to pursue them.

events.title: Bounty offered for Maxwell
events.description: The Sun newspaper offers a £10,000 reward for information on Ghislaine Maxwell.

events.title: Maxwell sues Epstein's estate
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell sues Jeffrey Epstein's estate, citing death threats and extensive legal fees.

keyFacts: Following Jeffrey Epstein's death in 2019, Ghislaine Maxwell became the primary public and media target, labeled 'Person #1' in the case.
A UK newspaper, The Sun, offered a £10,000 bounty for information on Ghislaine Maxwell in November 2019.
Ghislaine Maxwell faced intense public vitriol and death threats on social media, with calls for violence against her.
In March 2020, Ghislaine Maxwell sued Jeffrey Epstein's estate, citing the death threats and her legal fees as reasons.
